description: The verb is derived from Middle English strouten, struten (â€œto bulge, swell; to protrude, stick out; to bluster, threaten; to object forcefully; to create a disturbance; to fight; to display one's clothes in a proud or vain mannerâ€)Â [and other forms], from Old English strÅ«tian (â€œto project out; stand out stiffly; to exert oneself, struggleâ€), from Proto-Germanic *strÅ«tÅnÄ…, *strÅ«tijanÄ… (â€œto be puffed up, swellâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *streudÊ°- (â€œrigid, stiffâ€), from *(s)ter- (â€œfirm; strong; rigid, stiffâ€).

The English word is cognate with Danish strutte (â€œto bulge, bristleâ€), Low German strutt (â€œstiffâ€), Middle High German striuzen (â€œto bristle; to ruffleâ€) (modern German strotzen (â€œto bristle upâ€), strÃ¤uÃŸen (obsolete, except in Alemannic)); and compare Gothic ğŒ¸ğ‚ğŒ¿ğ„ğƒğ†ğŒ¹ğŒ»ğŒ» (Ã¾rutsfill, â€œleprosyâ€), Old Norse Ã¾rÃºtinn (â€œswollenâ€).

The noun is derived from the verb. Noun sense 2 (â€œinstrument for adjusting the pleats of a ruffâ€) appears to be due to a misreading of a 16th-century work which used the word stroout (strouted (â€œcaused (something) to bulge, protrude, or swell; struttedâ€)).

entries.meaning: (also figuratively) A step or walk done stiffly and with the head held high, often due to haughtiness or pride; affected dignity in walking.
(historical) An instrument for adjusting the pleats of a ruff.

verbs.description: strut (third-person singular simple present struts, present participle strutting, simple past and past participle strutted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a peacock or other fowl: to stand or walk stiffly, with the tail erect and spread out.
(intransitive, by extension, also figuratively) To walk haughtily or proudly with one's head held high.
examples: He strutted about the yard, thinking himself master of all he surveyed.

entries.meaning: (transitive, by extension) To walk across or on (a stage or other place) haughtily or proudly.
(intransitive, obsolete) Often followed by out: to protuberate or stick out due to being full or swollen; to bulge, to swell.
(transitive, obsolete) Often followed by out: to cause (something) to bulge, protrude, or swell.

description: The origin of sense 1 of the noun (â€œbeam or rod providing supportâ€) is unknown; it is probably ultimately from Proto-Germanic *strÅ«tÅnÄ…, *strÅ«tijanÄ… (â€œto be puffed up, swellâ€): see further at etymology 1. The English word is cognate with Icelandic strÃºtur (â€œhood jutting out like a hornâ€), Low German strutt (â€œrigid, stiffâ€), Norwegian strut (â€œnozzle, spoutâ€), Swedish strut (â€œpaper cornetâ€).
The verb is derived from sense 1 of the noun.
Sense 2 of the noun (â€œact of struttingâ€) is derived from the verb: see above.

entries.meaning: (chiefly construction) A beam or rod providing support.

An act of strutting (â€œbracing or supporting (something) by a strut or struts (sense 1); attaching diagonally; bending at a sharp angleâ€); specifically, deviation (of the spoke of a wheel) from the normal position.

verbs.description: strut (third-person singular simple present struts, present participle strutting, simple past and past participle strutted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly construction, also figuratively) To brace or support (something) by a strut or struts; to hold (something) in place or strengthen by a diagonal, transverse, or upright support.
(intransitive) To be attached diagonally or at a slant; also, to be bent at a sharp angle.

description: Probably an archaic past participle of strut (â€œto (cause something to) bulge, protrude, or swellâ€), now replaced by strutted: see etymology 1.

adjectives.description: strut (comparative more strut, superlative most strut)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Swelling out due to being full; bulging, protuberant, swollen.
